string.text: {=armeniaCultureDescription}Armenian culture, particularly in the Cilician Kingdom (1198–1375), blended native Armenian traditions with European, Byzantine, and Middle Eastern influences. As a Christian stronghold, it maintained close ties with Crusader states, adopting chivalric customs, Latin feudal law, and Gothic architectural elements. The nobility and warrior class defended the kingdom against Seljuk, Mamluk, and Mongol threats, while merchants made Cilicia a key trade hub between East and West. Armenian monasteries preserved scholarship, producing illuminated manuscripts and theological works. Peasants and artisans sustained the economy through agriculture and craftsmanship, while a rich oral tradition and unique church music reflected the kingdom’s vibrant identity.
